Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 613dabea03cd2f5cb999be37aaf539280c63ea7a
What about built-in objects? Any difference there between constructor call and brace initialization?
I'm not sure I understand the question.  What is an example of a built-in object?
I haven't measured the impact of that case specifically outside of nlohmann object.  In that specific case, I'm guessing it doesn't have much impact, but it's hard to say.

Any idea why brace initialization in nlohmann increases binary size? Is this a bug in that library?

https://github.com/nlohmann/json#json-as-first-class-data-type

Their examples have brace initialization.

> Any idea why brace initialization in nlohmann increases binary size?

Because you're constructing a non-trivial object, and there's some limit to the level of complexity that the compiler can optimize.

> Is this a bug in that library?

Definitely not.  MAYBE could be argued that it's a missing feature in the gcc optimizer, where one might argue that it should be able to optimize these to the same thing, but I'm guessing there's some code path where the intermediate object COULD throw an exception, so therefore the optimizer can't optimize it away.
maybe also mention how you find all the places?

manual inspection of all nlohmann::json objects and jsonValue objects;  I guess I can put that in the commit message, but it's not that interesting (it's not like I decompiled the binary or anything).

updated the commit message
Seems like a reasonable sanity test
Ack
nit, put ret near to where it is firstly used?
Fixed.
Done
Posted several questions. Otherwise LGTM.

This is just for my information.

Could you link me why "Xyz_t" types are used here but not Xyz directly? I remembered there are some changes before for this, but I didn't find an explanation.

You mean using nlohmann::json::object_t instead of nlohmann::json?

I've been doing that because the size of object_t/array_t is smaller, and more constrained in the types it can represent.

nlohmann::json foo = 0.1f;
is completely legal, which for most APIs that are passing a nlohmann type around would be a contract break.

nlohmann::json::object_t foo = 0.1f;  Wouldn't compile.

keep in mind, object_t is an alias to std::map<std::string, nlohmann::json, and array_t is an alias to std::vector<nlohmann::json>, so they're relatively simple objects, even if they're a complex alias.

when you do things like:
for (auto& element: nlohman::json foo())

to iterate an array or object, you incidentally construct a nlohmann::json::iteration_proxy object, which can technically throw if your type is incorrect.  When iterating an array_t or an object_t, there's no possibility to throw.

Now, all of the above are super micro optimizations that do decrease the binary size, but not by a ratio that actually matters..  The biggest thing for me is that there's exception safety and in code you're making your intent clear.

Thanks for these information.

I actually meant object_t vs object, array_t vs array

object is a method I think?  object_t is a type.  Unless I'm missing something, I don't think they're interchangable?

https://json.nlohmann.me/api/basic_json/object/
